Note that the following appears to be a partial transcript of the
screencast @

http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/tutorials/screencasts/tptpJunit.html

which is

* much more detailed (but only runs 5 min)
* for 4.0--dunno how much has changed

eclipsesource@... 12/07/2005 05:02 AM
 > Creating Tests Using the Test and Performance Tools Platform Plug-ins

 > Generally speaking, Eclipse's Test and Performance Tools Platform
 > (TPTP) provides a framework for building any testing tool. In
 > addition, TPTP uses its own framework to provide sample tools
 > supporting three types of testing:

 > * Performance testing of HTTP applications
 > * JUnit testing
 > * Manual testing

 > In this article, we'll see how to perform JUnit testing. I assume
 > you have the TPTP plug-ins installed in your Eclipse environment. If
 > you haven't installed them already, head to the TPTP project's Web
 > site

http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/index.html

 > for the latest downloads. To begin testing you need a class to
 > test. I started with a BankAccount class having the standard getter
 > and setter methods for accessing the account's ID, owner, and
 > balance fields. I also implemented default and fully parameterized
 > constructors. Finally, I wrote deposit(..) and withdraw(..) methods
 > for my class. Now it's time to test the class and see if I have
 > implemented it correctly.

 > The first step in JUnit testing using TPTP is to build a package to
 > include your test case and test suite classes. While not a strict
 > requirement for TPTP testing, it is a good practice to put your test
 > cases and suites in a separate package or project. For convenience,
 > my testing package is in the same project as my BankAccount class.

 > The second step is to select the testing package and using the right
 > mouse button, select New -> Other... in order to bring up the New
 > Wizard dialog shown in Figure 1.

http://www.bzmedia.com/esimage/20051207-1.gif

 > From this dialog, select TPTP JUnit Test. If this is your first
 > test, you will be asked to include specific testing libraries, as
 > shown in Figure 2.

http://www.bzmedia.com/esimage/20051207-2.gif

 > Select the Yes button.

 > As shown in Figure 3,

http://www.bzmedia.com/esimage/20051207-3.gif

 > next you identify your test case class. Clicking the Next button
 > lets you view exactly where your test class will be defined, as
 > shown in Figure 4.

http://www.bzmedia.com/esimage/20051207-4.gif

 > Clicking Next again lets you provide a description for your test
 > case. Finally, clicking the Finish Button creates your test case
 > Java class as well as a corresponding TPTP testsuite file. To
 > integrate with the TPTP testing framework, your test case Java class
 > extends the class HyadesTestCase, rather than JUnit's TestCase
 > class. However, it contains those familiar JUnit methods setup(),
 > teardown() and suite().

 > TPTP's testsuite file has its own editor that enables you to define
 > test methods and behavior for your test case. It also provides an
 > overview of your TPTP JUnit test. Double-clicking on your testsuite
 > file will open up the editor as shown in Figure 5.

http://www.bzmedia.com/esimage/20051207-5.gif

 > The description you entered in the previous wizard shows up in the
 > Overview tab. By selecting the Test Methods tab, you can enter new
 > test methods as shown in Figure 6.

http://www.bzmedia.com/esimage/20051207-6.gif

 > Performing this action creates corresponding method stubs in your
 > test case class that you can fill in with real testing code. Check
 > your test case class to make sure. Mine looks like the following
 > listing, with some code omitted:

 > package com.testing;

 > import org.eclipse.hyades.test.common.junit.DefaultTestArbiter;
 > import org.eclipse.hyades.test.common.junit.HyadesTestCase;
 > import org.eclipse.hyades.test.common.junit.HyadesTestSuite;

 > /**
 > * Generated code for the test suite BankAccountTestCase located at
 > * /Demo/src/com/testing/BankAccountTestCase.testsuite.
 > */
 > public class BankAccountTestCase extends HyadesTestCase {
 > /** *
 > Constructor for BankAccountTestCase.
 > * @param name
 > */ public BankAccountTestCase(String name)
 > { super(name);
 > }

 > /**
 > * @see junit.framework.TestCase#setUp()
 > */ protected void setUp() throws Exception { }
 > /**
 > * @see junit.framework.TestCase#tearDown()
 > */
 > protected void tearDown() throws Exception {
 > }
 > /**
 > * testDeposit
 > * @throws Exception
 > */ public void testDeposit()
 > throws Exception
 > {
 > // Enter your code here
 > }

 > /**
 > * testWithdraw
 > * @throws Exception
 > */ public void testWithdraw()
 > throws Exception
 > {
 > // Enter your code here }
 > }

 > After filling in your testing stub methods with actual testing code,
 > it's time to run the test. First, click the Behavior tab in your
 > testsuite editor, click the Add button, select the invocation option
 > and then select both your test methods, as shown in Figure 7.

http://www.bzmedia.com/esimage/20051207-7.gif

 > Next, type Ctrl-S to save your changes.

 > Select your testsuite file, and using the right mouse button, choose
 > Run As -> Test from the Context menu. Don't choose JUnit! What you
 > might see now is an error, as shown in Figure 8.

http://www.bzmedia.com/esimage/20051207-8.gif

 > If this happens, go back to the TPTP Web site and download the agent
 > controller runtime. Install the agent controller runtime and then
 > read its documentation. You will need to start up the agent
 > controller--done outside of Eclipse--

See

http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/installguide/AgentController41.html

 > before you run your TPTP tests in Eclipse.

 > Try running your test again. If all goes well, a
 > BankAccountTestCase.execution file is generated. Double click that
 > file. This action should bring up an Execution view, as shown in
 > Figure 9.

http://www.bzmedia.com/esimage/20051207-9.gif

 > By selecting the view's Overview or Events tab, you can view your
 > test results all the way down to the invocation of a single test
 > method.

 > Dwight Deugo
